history.content: One way to try open-ended research is to take the EE/CS 29X classes, that typically have a open-ended final project. These may lead you to new avenues of research and ideas.

children.subject:
Try asking whoever you are working with for additional research projects more similar to work that the other people are doing, on top of your current programming contributions; this will require extra work from you but will likely be viewed much more favorably since you are already a contributing member but is looking to contribute more than you already are.

Also as a side note, even the people that seem like they're doing really interesting stuff likely have a ton of grunt work they're also dealing with. Research, especially theory research, likely isn't as glamorous as you think it is within the realm of engineering; mainly due to the fact that to convince anybody that your theory result is, you will need a practical example to illustrate it. If you want research that isn't filled with grunt work, try looking to math.

Here's a few things to consider:

- you can always quit or "master out" of a PhD program

- you can always work before doing a PhD

- you can do a masters before PhD

- if your grades are high enough, you can apply to the EECS honors program and do an honor's thesis (for more research experience)

Personally, I know a grad student who worked for 10 years before doing a PhD here, and I know a Berkeley alum who quit his PhD after 6 months. Both of them are very happy doing what they are doing.

Pick something that makes sense now and that you like, and trust that you are smart and resourceful enough to make the necessary changes in the future. It's impossible to predict the future -- but since you're a Cal student, you'll end up someplace great no matter what you decide.

Hope this helps!

history.content:
I know this has been asked several times, but even after following the advice from other threads I'm still very lost. I've been told that doing research as an undergrad is the best way to figure out whether I want to pursue a masters/PhD in the future. This past semester I started doing that, and I've found the lab meetings where people present their work very interested (it's very ML/theory-oriented and cutting-edge research seems to interest me more than what I've done in industry internships).

However, within the research group, I myself have mostly been doing grunt work/basic Python coding, which is understandable since I am still an undergrad. The problem is that's probably not representative of what I'd actually do as a grad student / in future research roles, and in fact it feels more similar to industry work where I'm given a set of tasks and need to write code to accomplish it. From what I've heard from professors/friends, this is what typical undergraduate research is like since we simply don't have the necessary background yet to tackle the open-ended and highly theoretical questions ourselves.

As a result of this, I've been second-guessing whether my interest in other people's presentations at lab meetings is actually an interest in academia, or just a surface-level curiosity for "cool-sounding" topics and unfamiliar ideas. I'm afraid that if I do go into a PhD program, which would require committing 6+ years of my life, I might discover that I don't enjoy actually doing the research myself and that time would have been wasted.

Basically, I enjoy the classes I'm taking (where we're given math problems that have well-defined answers) and listening to others talk about their research, but I've never gotten the chance to do open-ended, serious research myself and I don't know if I expect to before finishing undergrad. At what point do people decide that their passion for academia is "real" and that grad school is a good choice?
history.subject: Deciding whether grad school is right for me
